title: Blunt Hepatic Injury
diagnosis_topic: Grade III liver laceration from blunt abdominal trauma
setup_script: “A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. She was the restrained driver and denies loss of consciousness. She complains of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. On arrival, she is hemodynamically stable. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “BP 120/78 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 37 °C, SpO₂ 99%.”
“Mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant without rebound or guarding.”
“Positive fluid in Morrison’s pouch; patient remains hemodynamically stable.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT scan with IV contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: “Grade III liver laceration with contained subcapsular hematoma; no other injuries identified.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates ICU observation with serial exams and hematocrit checks
dynamic_flow.reply: “Patient remains stable with no drop in hemoglobin after 6 hours.”
“Hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL, platelets 210,000/μL, mildly elevated liver enzymes.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults interventional radiology without indication
dynamic_flow.reply: “Interventional radiology notes no active arterial blush and advises that embolization is not required unless instability develops.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays intervention or prematurely discharges the patient
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient returns in shock with hypotension and tachycardia from delayed hemorrhage.”
“Patient remains stable, but possible complications include biliary leak, hemobilia, or intrahepatic abscess.”
“Initial bed rest followed by limited activity for 6 weeks; follow-up imaging arranged.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides counseling on injury prevention
dynamic_flow.reply: “Patient is counseled on seat belt safety and motor vehicle injury prevention.”

critical_decision_points: Assessment and initial evaluation of blunt abdominal trauma with potential hepatic injury
Appropriate use and interpretation of FAST and CT imaging
Decision-making regarding nonoperative management of liver injuries
Recognition and monitoring for delayed hemorrhage or complications
Patient counseling regarding recovery, activity restrictions, and injury prevention

anchors.3: Identifies hepatic injury but omits alternatives
anchors.4: Develops comprehensive differential, includes hepatic injury, and rules out alternatives
anchors.5: Quickly identifies hepatic injury, articulates complete differential with supporting and refuting data

anchors.5: Anticipates complications, coordinates multidisciplinary care, makes timely decisions

resident_feedback_template:
Strengths: You demonstrated sound diagnostic reasoning by appropriately recognizing blunt hepatic injury and selecting nonoperative management for a stable patient. Your communication was clear and structured, and you appropriately considered patient safety and injury prevention.
Areas for Improvement: Earlier discussion of monitoring for delayed hemorrhage and explicit planning for follow-up imaging would strengthen your management approach. Consider refining your explanation of the criteria for nonoperative versus operative intervention.
Suggested Reading Topics: - Management of Hepatic Trauma (SCORE) - EAST Practice Guidelines for Nonoperative Management of Blunt Hepatic Injuries - Complications after Liver Trauma and Their Management (ACS/ASE Review Manual)
